meeting_annotations.speaker: Rafael Santos
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah on this hybrid approaches another example I can give is that we do here in Guelph quite a bit is the production of biochar and then trying to use the biochar to replace coke in steel making. meeting_annotations.speaker: Andrea Hicks
meeting_annotations.transcript: Right so life cycle assessment typically relies on generalized inventories if you don't have particular inventories. So you can think about like anthracite mining right so it's a type of coal in the US. Europe's been a bit ahead of us on all of this in terms of developing the types of databases you use and Ecoinvent is one of the big ones. The US has the US life cycle inventory from the National Renewable Energy Laboratory which has some of the processes but it's missing so you usually need to fill in. And the USDA E-PACT actually has been putting together a lot of the agricultural databases. I mean agriculture is a little bit interesting right because like depending how you produce a kilogram of corn it could be vastly different in terms of things like added amendments water energy. So I mean I think the US is lagging a little bit behind on the actual inventory data to characterize our systems whereas Europe's been doing it for a while.
